title: Question 24
prompt:
Solubility is the amount of solute which can be dissolved in a solvent. Once a solution has reached the limit of the solute’s and solvent’s solubility, the solution is said to be saturated. For example, when salt is gradually added to water, stirring constantly, the salt will dissolve in the water until saturation is reached.

What will happen if more salt is added past the point of saturation?
feedback: Once a certain amount of salt is added to water, the salt and water solution becomes saturated. After the point of saturation, added salt can not dissolve in the water. Since salt is heavier than water, undissolved salt will start to settle towards the bottom of the container.
